article.headline: Stanford 78, UCLA 65
article.story: STANFORD, Calif. (AP) -- Whenever Chris Hernandez glanced at Stanford's bench, the dwindling number of teammates in uniform -- and Dan Grunfeld's crutches -- provided all the motivation he needed for the best game of his career. Hernandez scored eight of his career-high 37 points in the final 3½ minutes while carrying Stanford to its sixth straight victory over UCLA, 78-65 on Sunday. With their injuries piling up and their schedule dwindling, the Cardinal (15-9, 9-5 Pac-10) need every point they can get from their remarkable point guard. Hernandez hit five 3-pointers and went 13-for-22 with several tough baskets during the Cardinal's two lengthy runs spanning halftime. "You don't have these games all the time," Hernandez said. "It was a special night. I had energy throughout the game. Usually, I get tired at some point." Instead, Hernandez focused on his poor performance in Stanford's last win over UCLA -- and the absence of Grunfeld, who will have surgery Tuesday on his torn knee ligament. With outside shots, drives to the hoop and strong passing, Hernandez made sure Stanford didn't miss its leading scorer and the other injured Cardinal for at least one game. His energy was the difference in Stanford's third straight victory overall -- but it was no surprise to his teammates, who have nothing but praise for their top playmaker's ability to take charge in a key conference game. "We can always count on the guy to run our offense," said Matt Haryasz, who had 12 points and nine rebounds. "We would take him over any point guard in the league. He's capable of doing a lot, and they gave him a lot of open shots. Chris is a great shooter." Fred Washington also scored 12 points as Stanford finished up a home sweep of the Los Angeles schools and took a comfortable hold on third place in the Pac-10 standings, 1½ games ahead of UCLA with a tiebreaker edge over the Bruins. Dijon Thompson had 19 points and 11 rebounds for the Bruins (14-9, 8-7), who have lost to all three teams ahead of them in the standings over the past five games. Freshman Jordan Farmar had 16 points and seven assists for UCLA, which had little of the offensive spark it showed in a win over California on Thursday, frequently settling for poor shots. Farmar struggled in his matchup with Hernandez, making seven turnovers and failing to stay with the Stanford junior on defense. "We couldn't locate Chris Hernandez all night, for some reason," Thompson said. "Stanford isn't stronger than we are. They're just more physical on defense. Pressure and aggressiveness, that's what took us out of our offense. When a player like (Hernandez) gets hot, you saw what happened." With Grunfeld out for the season, Hernandez knows the Cardinal's postseason success could depend on his ability to score while still balancing his favorite role as Stanford's best playmaker. So Hernandez was aggressive and accurate from the start, scoring 22 points and hitting three 3-pointers on 8-for-13 shooting in the first half. "It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know Chris Hernandez is our best player right now," coach Trent Johnson said. "We want the ball in his hands as much as possible." Washington had five steals in the first half, and Stanford went into halftime on a 23-8 run. Stanford then opened the second half on a 21-9 run, including six points from Haryasz. UCLA made a 17-5 run to cut Stanford's lead to 10 points with 4:48 to play, but Hernandez made a layup and two free throws to exceed his previous career-high, set earlier this season in an overtime victory over San Francisco. "We don't match up against them well," UCLA coach Ben Howland said. "Hernandez knows that with his team's leading scorer out, he's going to have to be the guy. He's looking to do whatever it takes to help his team." Hernandez capped his performance with a 3-pointer from two steps behind the line with 10 seconds left. Former Stanford star Josh Childress, now a rookie with the Atlanta Hawks, watched from a seat next to new Cardinal football coach Walt Harris.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
